metadata.titleEn: Dataset of high-resolution (3 hour, 10 km) global surface solar radiation (1983-2018)
metadata.description: The dataset is a nearly 36-year (1983.7-2018.12) high-resolution (3 h, 10 km) global SSR (surface solar radiation) dataset, which can be used for hydrological modeling, land surface modeling and engineering application. The dataset was produced based on ISCCP-HXG cloud products, ERA5 reanalysis data, and MODIS aerosol and albedo products with an improved physical parameterization scheme. Validation and comparisons with other global satellite radiation products indicate that our SSR estimates were generally better than those of the ISCCP flux dataset (ISCCP-FD), the global energy and water cycle experiment surface radiation budget (GEWEX-SRB), and the Earth's Radiant Energy System (CERES). This SSR dataset will contribute to the land-surface process simulations and the photovoltaic applications in the future. The unit is W/㎡, instantaneous value.
metadata.instructions: Each data file is named as ISCCP_HXG_global_radiation_YYYY_MM_DD_HH.nc (e.g. ISCCP_HXG_global_radiation_2000_01_01_00.nc), where YYYY is the four-digital year, MM is the two-digital month, DD is the two-digital day, HH is the two-digital hour, that means one file contains data for only one hour, additionally, .nc is the file name suffix which indicates that the data were stored as NetCDF format; For more information about NetCDF, please see http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/netcdf.

background: Surface solar radiation (SSR), which drives the energy, water and carbon cycles of Earth’s system, is the driving input for simulations of hydrology, ecology, agriculture and land-surface processes. The accuracy of SSR data influences simulations of runoff, gross primary productivity, growth and yield of crops, and land data assimilation. SSR is also an important variable that affects the speed of glacier melting. Variations of SSR also affect the rate of global warming and the change of pan evaporation. Information on the spatiotemporal distribution of SSR is fundamental for the selection of sites for solar power plants, decisions on energy policy, optimization of solar power systems and operations management. Measurement by the accurately calibrated and well-maintained radiometer of pyranometer is the most effective method to obtain reliable long-term SSR data. Although these data are valuable for simulations of land surface processes, solar power applications and evaluation of satellite retrievals, the high cost of maintaining radiation radiometers means that networks of radiation stations are too sparsely distributed. However, networks of routine meteorological stations are denser than those of radiation stations, and the variables observed at routine meteorological stations can be used to estimate SSR.
research objective: This study produced a 16-year (2000–2015) global dataset of SSR (with resolutions of 3 h and 10 km) based on recently updated ISCCP H-series cloud products, new ERA5 reanalysis data and MODIS albedo and aerosol products with a physically based scheme.
challenges: However, station-based estimates of SSR can be conducted only at routine weather stations, many of which are sparsely distributed, often in remote regions and harsh environments.
methods: The estimated SSR data were evaluated against surface observations measured at 42 stations of the Baseline Surface Radiation Network (BSRN) and 90 radiation stations of the China Meteorological Administration (CMA).
dataset: The recent release of the International Satellite Cloud Climatology Project (ISCCP) HXG cloud products and new ERA5 reanalysis data enabled us to produce a global surface solar radiation (SSR) dataset: a 16-year (2000–2015) high-resolution (3 h, 10 km) global SSR dataset using an improved physical parameterization scheme. The main inputs were cloud optical depth from ISCCP-HXG cloud products; the water vapor, surface pressure and ozone from ERA5 reanalysis data; and albedo and aerosol from Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) products.
findings: Validation against the BSRN data indicated that the mean bias error (MBE), root mean square error (RMSE) and correlation coefficient (R) for the instantaneous SSR estimates at 10 km scale were −11.5 W m−2, 113.5 W m−2 and 0.92, respectively. When the estimated instantaneous SSR data were up-scaled to 90 km, its error was clearly reduced, with RMSE decreasing to 93.4 W m−2 and R increasing to 0.95. For daily SSR estimates at 90 km scale, the MBE, RMSE and R at the BSRN were −5.8 W m−2, 33.1 W m−2 and 0.95, respectively. These error metrics at the CMA radiation stations were 2.1 W m−2, 26.9 W m−2 and 0.95, respectively. Comparisons with other global satellite radiation products indicated that our SSR estimates were generally better than those of the ISCCP flux dataset (ISCCP-FD), the global energy and water cycle experiment surface radiation budget (GEWEX-SRB), and the Earth’s Radiant Energy System (CERES).

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'surface solar radiation (SSR)' in land surface and solar power simulations?
Definition.Answer: Surface solar radiation (SSR) is crucial as it drives the energy, water, and carbon cycles of Earth’s system, serving as a vital input for simulations of hydrology, ecology, agriculture, and land-surface processes. It influences simulations of runoff, gross primary productivity, crop growth and yield, and land data assimilation. SSR also affects glacier melting rates, global warming, and pan evaporation changes. Accurate SSR data is fundamental for selecting sites for solar power plants, optimizing solar power systems, and managing operations.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with station-based estimates of surface solar radiation (SSR) data collection?
Definition.Answer: Station-based estimates of SSR face challenges due to the sparse distribution of radiation stations, many of which are located in remote regions and harsh environments. Moreover, the high cost of maintaining radiation radiometers limits the number of radiation stations, although routine meteorological stations, which are denser, can be used to estimate SSR by observing relevant variables.

Definition.Question: What are the key inputs and validation methods used in producing a high-resolution surface solar radiation (SSR) dataset?
Definition.Answer: The production of a high-resolution SSR dataset involves key inputs such as cloud optical depth from ISCCP-HXG cloud products, water vapor, surface pressure, and ozone from ERA5 reanalysis data, and albedo and aerosol from MODIS products. Validation of the estimated SSR data is conducted against surface observations measured at Baseline Surface Radiation Network (BSRN) stations and China Meteorological Administration (CMA) radiation stations, evaluating metrics like mean bias error (MBE), root mean square error (RMSE), and correlation coefficient (R).

Comparison.Question: How do station-based estimates of surface solar radiation (SSR) compare to the SSR data generated from satellite-derived products, such as ISCCP-HXG and ERA5?
Comparison.Answer: Station-based estimates of SSR can only be conducted at routine weather stations, which are often sparsely distributed. In contrast, satellite-derived products like ISCCP-HXG and ERA5 provide global data coverage using improved physical parameterization schemes. These satellite-derived products have been validated against surface observations, showing a high correlation and lower errors compared to other global satellite radiation products.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data input sources between the 16-year global SSR dataset and other global satellite radiation products?
Comparison.Answer: The 16-year global SSR dataset uses inputs from ISCCP-HXG cloud products, ERA5 reanalysis data, and MODIS albedo and aerosol products. This differs from other global satellite radiation products like ISCCP-FD, GEWEX-SRB, and CERES, which may use different input sources and parameterization schemes.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of maintaining radiation radiometers affect the data quality and coverage of SSR measurements compared to using variables from routine meteorological stations?
Comparison.Answer: Maintaining radiation radiometers is costly, leading to sparse distribution of radiation stations, which affects data coverage. However, variables from routine meteorological stations, which are denser, can be used to estimate SSR, potentially providing broader coverage despite possible compromises in direct measurement accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of cloud optical depth, water vapor, surface pressure, and ozone data into a physical parameterization scheme improve the accuracy of surface solar radiation datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of cloud optical depth from ISCCP-HXG cloud products, water vapor, surface pressure, and ozone from ERA5 reanalysis data in a physical parameterization scheme helps produce a high-resolution global surface solar radiation dataset. This integration enhances accuracy by utilizing comprehensive atmospheric variables that influence solar radiation reaching the surface, allowing for more precise SSR estimates.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise when attempting to estimate surface solar radiation at routine weather stations, and how can data from these stations be effectively utilized?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in estimating surface solar radiation at routine weather stations include their sparse distribution and locations in remote or harsh environments. Despite these challenges, variables observed at these stations can be used to estimate SSR, providing valuable data for simulations, though the estimates might be limited by the stations' geographic and environmental constraints.

Interpretation.Question: What potential improvements or refinements could be made to the methodologies used for validating SSR datasets against surface observations?
Interpretation.Answer: Potential improvements could involve expanding the number of validation sites beyond the current 42 BSRN and 90 CMA stations to include more diverse climatic regions. Additionally, refining the methodologies to account for local environmental factors affecting SSR and incorporating advanced statistical techniques for error reduction could enhance validation accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for improved physical parameterization schemes in generating high-resolution surface solar radiation datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for improved physical parameterization schemes arises due to the challenges in accurately estimating surface solar radiation from station-based measurements, which are often limited by sparse distribution, especially in remote and harsh environments. Improved schemes can better utilize satellite cloud products, reanalysis data, and other inputs to enhance estimation accuracy.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the higher accuracy of certain global satellite radiation datasets compared to others?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The higher accuracy of certain global satellite radiation datasets can be attributed to the use of advanced data inputs and improved methodological approaches, such as enhanced parameterization schemes that integrate inputs from various sources like MODIS albedo and aerosol products, leading to more reliable surface solar radiation estimates.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on data accuracy when using improved physical parameterization schemes with inputs from multiple satellite and reanalysis data sources for generating surface solar radiation datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using improved physical parameterization schemes with inputs from sources like ISCCP-HXG, ERA5, and MODIS generally results in higher accuracy for surface solar radiation datasets. Comparisons with other global satellite radiation products have shown that the estimates are more accurate than those from ISCCP-FD, GEWEX-SRB, and CERES.

Causal Consequence.Question: How do sparse distributions of radiation stations affect the reliability of surface solar radiation data and what alternative data collection methods can mitigate these effects?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Sparse distributions of radiation stations can limit the reliability of surface solar radiation data due to the high costs and challenging environments for maintaining radiometers. However, estimates of SSR can be made using variables from denser networks of routine meteorological stations, enhancing data reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What potential consequences arise from validating estimated surface solar radiation data against observations from networks like the Baseline Surface Radiation Network and the China Meteorological Administration?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Validating estimated surface solar radiation data against observations from networks such as the Baseline Surface Radiation Network and the China Meteorological Administration ensures the data's accuracy. It has been observed that validation reduces errors significantly, with metrics like RMSE and correlation coefficient improving, thereby enhancing the credibility of the dataset.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of creating a high-resolution global surface solar radiation dataset using inputs like ISCCP-HXG cloud products and ERA5 reanalysis data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to produce a comprehensive and accurate dataset that can drive simulations of hydrology, ecology, agriculture, and land-surface processes, enhancing the understanding and modeling of the Earth's energy, water, and carbon cycles. This data is essential for applications such as solar power generation, land data assimilation, and evaluation of satellite retrievals.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to evaluate estimated solar radiation data against observations from networks like the Baseline Surface Radiation Network and the China Meteorological Administration?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Evaluating estimated solar radiation data against observations is crucial for ensuring the accuracy and reliability of the dataset. This validation helps in identifying and reducing errors, thereby improving the dataset's utility for various applications, including simulations of land surface processes and solar power applications.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumental methods are used to validate a global surface solar radiation dataset against observational data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The estimated solar radiation data were validated against surface observations measured at 42 stations of the Baseline Surface Radiation Network (BSRN) and 90 radiation stations of the China Meteorological Administration (CMA).

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in generating a high-resolution global surface solar radiation dataset using satellite and reanalysis data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The dataset was produced using a physically based scheme with inputs such as cloud optical depth from ISCCP-HXG cloud products, water vapor, surface pressure, and ozone from ERA5 reanalysis data, and albedo and aerosol from MODIS products.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What challenges are associated with estimating surface solar radiation at routine weather stations, and how can these be addressed procedurally?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Station-based estimates of surface solar radiation can only be conducted at routine weather stations, which are often sparsely distributed and located in remote or harsh environments. This challenge can be addressed by utilizing denser networks of routine meteorological stations and employing data from these stations to estimate solar radiation.

Enablement.Question: What advancements in satellite technology and data processing techniques have enabled the creation of global high-resolution surface solar radiation datasets?
Enablement.Answer: The creation of global high-resolution surface solar radiation datasets has been enabled by the recent release of the International Satellite Cloud Climatology Project (ISCCP) HXG cloud products, new ERA5 reanalysis data, and MODIS albedo and aerosol products, which allow for improved physical parameterization schemes.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do high-resolution datasets enable more precise simulations for hydrology and land surface processes?
Enablement.Answer: High-resolution datasets enable more precise simulations for hydrology and land surface processes by providing accurate surface solar radiation (SSR) data, which is a critical input for simulations affecting runoff, gross primary productivity, crop growth and yield, and land data assimilation.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of routine meteorological station data introduce challenges in estimating surface solar radiation (SSR) accurately?
Expectation.Answer: Station-based estimates of SSR can be conducted only at routine weather stations, many of which are sparsely distributed, often in remote regions and harsh environments.

Expectation.Question: Why could there be an expectation for improved accuracy in SSR datasets when using data from sources like ISCCP-HXG cloud products and ERA5 reanalysis data?
Expectation.Answer: The recent release of ISCCP-HXG cloud products and new ERA5 reanalysis data enabled the production of a global SSR dataset with improved physical parameterization, which typically offers better accuracy compared to other global satellite radiation products.

Expectation.Question: What might be the reasons for the observed error reduction when SSR data is up-scaled from a 10 km resolution to a 90 km resolution?
Expectation.Answer: Validation against the BSRN data indicated that up-scaling the estimated SSR data from 10 km to 90 km resolution significantly reduced the RMSE and increased the correlation coefficient, possibly due to averaging effects that mitigate localized errors.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the potential of satellite-derived datasets, like ERA5 and MODIS, in improving the accuracy of global surface solar radiation estimates?
Judgmental.Answer: Satellite-derived datasets such as ERA5 and MODIS have significant potential to improve the accuracy of global surface solar radiation estimates. These datasets provide high-resolution information, like cloud optical depth and aerosol products, which enhance the precision of SSR measurements when integrated with improved physical parameterization schemes.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, what are the primary challenges that need to be addressed to enhance the spatial and temporal resolution of global surface solar radiation datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: The primary challenges in enhancing the spatial and temporal resolution of global surface solar radiation datasets include the sparse distribution of measurement stations, especially in remote and harsh environments, and the need for continuous and accurate calibration of instruments. Additionally, integrating various satellite data products with advanced parameterization schemes is crucial to overcoming these challenges.

Assertion.Question: I can't understand how SSR data are collected with high accuracy given the sparse distribution of radiation stations.
Assertion.Answer: Measurement by the accurately calibrated and well-maintained radiometer of pyranometer is the most effective method to obtain reliable long-term SSR data. Although networks of radiation stations are sparse, SSR data can be estimated using data from denser networks of routine meteorological stations.

Assertion.Question: I'm not sure how a global SSR dataset can be reliably produced with different data sources and methodologies.
Assertion.Answer: A global SSR dataset can be produced using a combination of ISCCP H-series cloud products, ERA5 reanalysis data, and MODIS albedo and aerosol products with a physically based scheme. The estimation process involves improved physical parameterization and validation against surface observations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the effectiveness of using satellite-derived products in generating high-resolution surface solar radiation datasets compared to traditional ground-based measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: Satellite-derived products such as the International Satellite Cloud Climatology Project (ISCCP) HXG cloud products, ERA5 reanalysis data, and MODIS albedo and aerosol products were used to produce a high-resolution global surface solar radiation dataset. Validation against surface observations measured at Baseline Surface Radiation Network (BSRN) and other stations indicated that the satellite-derived estimates were generally more accurate than traditional global satellite radiation products.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a research approach to improve the parameterization scheme used in generating surface solar radiation datasets, considering the integration of emerging data sources.
Request/Directive.Answer: An improved physical parameterization scheme was used to generate the surface solar radiation dataset, integrating inputs such as cloud optical depth from ISCCP-HXG cloud products, water vapor, surface pressure, ozone from ERA5 reanalysis data, and albedo and aerosol from MODIS products. To further improve the parameterization scheme, a research approach could involve integrating emerging data sources like advanced satellite sensors or machine learning techniques for better accuracy and resolution.
